para.text: Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives

The Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives (“GOCI”) shall include the following units, created by Executive Order: the Governor’s Commission on African Affairs, the Governor’s Commission on Asian and Pacific American Affairs, the Governor’s Commission on Caribbean Affairs, the Governor’s Commission on Hispanic and Latin American Community Affairs, the Governor’s Commission on Middle Eastern American Affairs, and the Governor’s Commission on South Asian American Affairs (together, the “Ethnic Commissions”), and any other commission designated by the Governor as a unit of GOCI.
GOCI also houses the legislatively created Commission on Indian Affairs, Commission on LGBTQIA+ Affairs, and Governor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs.
Executive Director. GOCI shall be managed by an Executive Director, who serves at the pleasure of the Governor. The Executive Director shall:
Supervise, direct, manage, and coordinate the Ethnic Commissions designated in Section 1.A of this Order;
Provide administrative supervision and support to the legislatively created units designated in Section 1.B of this Order;

Direct community initiatives across State government and coordinate with federal and local governments, private sector entities, academia, and community organizations to strengthen community engagement; and
Represent the Governor on boards, forums, and councils as appropriate.
Staffing.
GOCI shall be composed of staff appointed by the Executive Director, with the approval of the Governor.
GOCI staff serve at the pleasure of the Executive Director, subject to the concurrence of the Governor.
Duties. GOCI shall be responsible for the following activities:

Conducting a review of State programs in cooperation with appropriate State departments and agencies to identify legislative and regulatory barriers that impede the effectiveness of community organizations to deliver results-based social services;
Advising the Governor on policies and measures to enhance and improve the delivery of services to ethnic, immigrant, and faith-based communities;
Conducting public outreach on behalf of the Governor to encourage greater involvement and participation by community organizations and constituent groups;
Reviewing State and federal legislation to assist in the identification of funding opportunities for community organizations to implement initiatives that benefit the State of Maryland; and
Serving as principal liaison to the faith-based community and associated organizations.
All State departments, agencies, commissions, and boards are directed to cooperate with GOCI in implementing the provisions of this Executive Order.
Reports. By December 31 of each year, GOCI shall submit an annual report to the Governor on its activities.
Ethnic Commissions
There are the following Ethnic Commissions within GOCI:
The Governor’s Commission on African Affairs;
The Governor’s Commission on Asian and Pacific American Affairs;
The Governor’s Commission on Caribbean Affairs;
The Governor’s Commission on Hispanic and Latin American Community Affairs;
The Governor’s Commission on Middle Eastern American Affairs; and
The Governor’s Commission on South Asian American Affairs.
Membership.
Each Ethnic Commission shall consist of fifteen (15) voting members appointed by the Governor.
The Commission members shall:
Reflect the diverse ancestry and national origins of the respective communities of Maryland; and
Provide representation from different geographic regions in the State.
Members shall serve at the pleasure of the Governor consecutive four-year terms.
If a member is appointed to a vacant seat with less than two years remaining in a term, such service does not count as a full term. Such a member is eligible to serve two additional four-year terms.
A Commission member holds a seat until a successor is appointed.
The Governor shall designate a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among the members of the Commission. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson shall serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
In the event of a vacancy on a Commission, the Governor shall appoint a successor.
Commission members are subject to the direction of the Executive Director and serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
Eligibility and Appointment.
Members of the Ethnic Commissions shall demonstrate an affinity to the diasporic community that the commission represents. A Commission member may demonstrate affinity by being:
An immigrant of a diasporic community;
A descendant of a diasporic community;
A proven advocate for the interests of a diasporic community;
A scholar or educator of the history of a diasporic community;
An expert on issues important to a diaspora community; or
A former resident of a diasporic community.
In making appointments to the Ethnic Commissions, the Governor shall consider the demographic and geographic diversity of the State.
Procedures. The following procedures govern the Ethnic Commissions:
The Commissions are public bodies subject to the Open Meetings Act.
The Commissions shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, in coordination with GOCI, at least six times each year. Sufficient notice of meetings shall be published to encourage public attendance.
The Commissions shall hold at least one administrative planning session each year for onboarding and scheduling purposes.
A majority of the Commission members then serving shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business.
The Commissions may adopt such other procedures and by-laws as may be necessary to ensure the orderly transaction of business.
The Commissions may create committees or subcommittees subject to the approval of the Executive Director.
By June 30th of each year, the Commissions shall submit an annual report to the Governor detailing the activities in the preceding calendar year, along with any appropriate recommendations.

Expenses. Ethnic Commission members may not receive any compensation for their services, but may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations, and as provided in the State budget.
Operational Support. GOCI shall provide publication, operational, and other support as needed to the Ethnic Commissions.
Duties. The Ethnic Commissions shall have the following duties and responsibilities:

Serve as an advisory body to the Governor and agencies within the Executive Department on matters relating to the Commission’s diasporic community within Maryland, including matters relating to economic, workforce, and business development domestically and abroad;
Identify needs or problems affecting the Commission’s diasporic community, and make recommendations to the Governor on appropriate responses and programs;
Conduct outreach to the Commission’s diasporic community groups within the State, and communicate information to them concerning public and private programs that are beneficial to their interests;

Review and provide recommendations to the Governor on any proposed federal, State, or local legislation, regulations, policies, or programs that affect the Commission’s diasporic community of Maryland;
Make recommendations to the Governor on matters affecting the health, safety, and welfare of the Commission’s diasporic community of Maryland; and
Perform any other duties that may be requested by the Governor or the Executive Director.
The diasporic communities of the Ethnic Commissions are as follows:

Governor’s Commission on African Affairs: The diasporic countries of the Governor’s Commission on African Affairs include, but are not limited to: Algeria, Angola, Benin, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Cabo Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Cote d’Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Eswatini, Ethiopia, Gabon, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, Libya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mauritius, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Niger, Nigeria, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania, Togo, Tunisia, Uganda, Western Sahara, Zambia, Zimbabwe.

Governor’s Commission on Asian and Pacific American Affairs: The diasporic countries, territories, and states of the Governor’s Commission on Asian and Pacific American Affairs include, but are not limited to: Brunei, Cambodia, China, Cook Islands, East Timor, Federated States of Micronesia, Fiji, Guam, Hawaii, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kazakhstan, Kiribati, Kyrgyzstan, Laos, Lord Howe Island, Macau, Malaysia, Melanesia, Micronesia, Mongolia, Myanmar, Norfolk Island, North Korea, Oceanic islands of the Eastern Pacific, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Polynesia, Republic of Marshall Islands, Samoa, Singapore, Solomon Islands, South Korea, Taiwan, Tajikistan, Thailand, the Revillagigedo Islands, Tonga, Turkmenistan, Tuvalu, Uzbekistan, Vanuatu, Vietnam.

Governor’s Commission on Caribbean Affairs: The diasporic countries of the Governor’s Commission on Caribbean Affairs include, but are not limited to: Anguilla, Antigua and Barbuda, Aruba, the Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Cuba, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Grenada, Guadeloupe, Haiti, Jamaica, Martinique, Montserrat, Netherlands Antilles, Puerto Rico, St. Barths, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Martin, St. Vincent, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks and Caicos.

Governor’s Commission on Hispanic and Latin American Community Affairs: The diasporic countries of the Governor’s Commission on Hispanic and Latin American Affairs include, but are not limited to: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Columbia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Equatorial Guinea, French Guyana, Guatemala, Guyana, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Spain, Uruguay, Venezuela.

Governor’s Commission on Middle Eastern American Affairs: The diasporic countries of the Governor’s Commission on Middle Eastern American Affairs include, but are not limited to: Bahrain, Cyprus, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Oman, Palestine, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Turkey, United Arab Emirates, Yemen.

Governor’s Commission on South Asian Affairs: The diasporic countries of the Governor’s Commission on South Asian Affairs include, but are not limited to: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka.
Establishment.

There is a Digital Infrastructure Group (“DIG”) in the Department of Information Technology (“DoIT” or the “Department”) whose purpose is to coordinate the efficient deployment of wired and wireless communications and digital information technology infrastructure among the various State, County and local partners.
The Chair of the DIG shall be designated by the Secretary of DoIT (“Secretary”) and shall serve at the pleasure of the Secretary.
Responsibilities.
The DIG shall:
Develop, promote, and facilitate a Statewide vision for wired and wireless communications and digital information technology infrastructure;
Promote collaboration among State, County and local agencies for the management and deployment of wired and wireless communications and digital information technology infrastructure;
Communicate current and future wired and wireless communications and broadband infrastructure plans to relevant stakeholders;

Develop recommendations for long-range plans for wired and wireless communications and broadband infrastructure consistent with State goals, objectives, and DoIT’s Statewide Information Technology Master Plan;
Develop recommendations for policy, regulations, or legislation to facilitate strengthening Maryland’s wired and wireless communications, broadband, and information technology infrastructure;
Advise on the planning, funding, and development of Statewide wired and wireless communications, broadband, and information technology infrastructure projects proposed by units of State government;

Identify opportunities for productive partnerships and the use of new technologies, including public-private partnerships, that enable the sharing of resources and further the goal of expanding and strengthening Maryland’s wired and wireless communications, broadband, and information technology infrastructure; and

Ensure best management practices are employed for the use of State resources, assets, licenses, and funding and that these uses are consistent with State goals and objectives as well as DoIT’s Statewide Information Technology Master Plan.
Composition.

The DIG shall be composed of senior State officials from DoIT, designated by the Secretary, and senior staff members from the following agencies or units of State Government, designated by the respective agency or unit head:
The Maryland State Police (MSP);
The Maryland Department of Transportation and its Transportation Business Units (MDOT & TBU’s);
The Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems (MIEMSS);
The Department of Natural Resources (DNR);
The Governor’s Office of Homeland Security;
The Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD);
The Maryland Public Broadcasting Commission (MPT);
The Department of General Services (DGS);
The Maryland Department of Emergency Management (MDEM);
The Department of Budget and Management (DBM);
The Office of the Statewide Interoperability Coordinator (SWIC); and
The Statewide Interoperability Executive Committee (SIEC).
The Secretary may appoint additional members from units of State and local governmental entities as necessary.
The Secretary may establish one or more working groups and or subcommittees as necessary in support of the DIG.
Contributions, Goals, and Objectives.

In consultation with the DIG, DoIT shall create a “Single View” of State-owned wired and wireless communications, broadband, and information technology infrastructure inventory inclusive of all inground, aerial and vertical assets. The “Single View” will include, at a minimum, each Executive Branch agency's qualifying assets and all approved Resource Sharing Agreement installations. The “Single View” shall be used for long-range planning, joint build projects, promoting Resource Share Agreement (RSA) opportunities and in support of broadband and digital infrastructure expansion.

DIG members shall share wired and wireless communications, broadband, and information technology infrastructure data with the Department to be included in the “Single View” that shall facilitate the consideration of how and where future wired and wireless infrastructure is deployed in the State.

In consultation with DIG, DoIT shall aggregate the various information technology policy-related advice generated by the various Executive Branch agencies, Statewide Interoperability Executive Committee, Statewide Interoperability Coordinator, and State Radio Control Board in order to provide recommendations and advice to the Secretary.

DIG members shall seek opportunities to strategically plan and design a shared infrastructure model that effectively manages public real property information technology corridors and efficiently uses monetary resources to generate cost savings.
Ensure DIG priorities are considered when evaluating RSA opportunities.
Improve broadband access and digital equity across the State.
Address last-mile connectivity, particularly in rural areas.
Provide strategies to achieve the availability of increased connectivity speeds to every Community Anchor Institution (CAI).
Collaborate on how best to employ available funding, to include State and Federal Grants, to achieve the maximum coverage in the most effective manner.
Frequency.
The Secretary shall determine how often DIG shall meet and may coordinate additional meetings dependent on workload.
The Secretary shall determine how often each working group or subcommittee established under this Executive Order shall meet.

Each Executive Branch agency and unit of State government is hereby required, to the extent not inconsistent with law, to cooperate fully with DIG and to furnish such assistance, including data, reports, or other information as necessary to accomplish the purpose of this Executive Order.
Nothing contained in this Executive Order shall be construed to impair or otherwise affect the authority granted by law to an Executive Branch agency or unit of State government.

This Executive Order shall be implemented in a manner that is consistent with all applicable statutes and regulations. Nothing in this Executive Order shall operate to contravene any State or federal law or to affect the State’s receipt of federal funding.

If any provision of this Executive Order or its application to any person, entity, or circumstance is held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions or applications of the Executive Order shall remain in effect to the extent possible without the invalid provision or application. To achieve this purpose, the provisions of this Executive Order are severable.

Governor’s Office of Performance Improvement. The Governor’s Office of Performance Improvement (“GOPI”) shall be responsible for improving the performance of Maryland State agencies through greater accountability, coordination, and capacity building.
GOPI shall be managed by the Chief Performance Officer, who shall direct the operations of GOPI. The Chief Performance Officer shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
GOPI shall be comprised of staff appointed by the Governor.
Duties. GOPI shall:

Develop the State Comprehensive Plan (“State Plan”), as defined in §3-1001 of the State Finance & Procurement Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland, at the outset of a new gubernatorial administration, which shall:
Include a statement of goals which serve as broad directives for improving or making more cost-effective State resources and services; and
Align State programs and services with the Governor’s priorities.
Direct State agencies to develop objectives, strategies, key milestones, and/or performance measures to track the State Plan implementation.
Develop and implement common sense government modernization initiatives as well as improve State operations and service delivery in order to:
Ensure strategic resource management.
Maintain fiscal sustainability.
Promote cost optimization strategies to ensure receipt of the highest value for state expenditures; and
Elimination duplication and fragmentation.
Hold State agencies accountable for delivering results, and maintain a data-driven approach to performance improvement and decision-making by:
Tracking progress on the State Plan and government-modernization initiatives;
Holding regular data-driven reviews with the Governor; Lieutenant Governor; and/or agency leaders;
Identifying areas for improvement and/or key actions;
Building agency capacity to support a data-driven, action-oriented culture within State government; and
Leveraging social science and evidence of best practices to ensure results for Marylanders.

Establish a Performance Improvement Council (“PIC”) composed of State agency representatives to provide a forum for the exchange of ideas to enable continuous improvement in the delivery of government services, accountability, and cross-agency collaboration.
Procedures
Each State agency and department of the Executive Branch shall appoint a performance lead to drive performance improvement at their agency, and who shall be primarily responsible for:
Providing access to the data requested by GOPI to determine progress being made by the agency;
Collaborating with GOPI to analyze the collected data; and
Following-up on areas of improvement identified by GOPI.
On a regular basis, each Secretary or agency head, or their designee, shall meet with GOPI.
The State agencies and departments of the Executive Branch shall build a data-driven, action-oriented culture that is accountable for delivering results.
All State agencies, departments, and boards and commissions within the Executive Branch are authorized and directed to cooperate with GOPI in implementing the provisions of this Executive Order.

This Executive Order shall not be construed to alter existing authorities of any Executive agency or department, except that all Executive agencies and departments are directed to assist the GOPI in carrying out the purposes of this Executive Order.

section.heading:
ENSURING SUCCESS WITH ADVANCED CLEAN CARS II
AND ADVANCED CLEAN TRUCKS IN MARYLAND

para.heading: Enforcement Discretion.
para.text: The Maryland Department of the Environment shall work with OEMs to ease the burdens created by the current federal Administration on ACC II and ACT compliance, including by, but not limited to, the following:
Maximizing the Department's use of enforcement discretion as necessary and appropriate to ease compliance with ACC II and ACT standards, including:

For the ACT standards, declining to pursue penalties associated with any ZEV delivery or sales shortfalls for Model Year 2027, and declining to pursue penalties for shortfalls in Model Year 2028 unless the Department publishes the Needs Assessment and Deployment Plan required by the Clean Trucks Act of 2023 by December 1, 2025;

For the ACC II standards, declining to pursue penalties associated with any ZEV delivery shortfalls for Model Year 2027 and Model Year 2028 unless the Department is carrying out voluntary agreements with OEMs collectively representing at least 40% of the State's market share for passenger car and light truck vehicles subject to ACC II; and
Discretion to decline the application of enforcement provisions under ACT and ACC II associated with any ZEV delivery shortfalls for Model Year 2027 and Model year 2028;
Making any regulatory changes permitted by the Clean Air Act to ease any compliance burdens caused by changes in federal policy; and
Continuing to work with CARB and other states that adopted CARB regulations under Section 177 to counter the harmful impacts of the current federal administration's policies.

para.heading: Establishment.
para.text: There is hereby established a Maryland ACC II and ACT Working Group ("Working Group").

para.heading: Purpose.
para.text: The Working Group shall develop recommendations for how the ACC II and ACT programs can be successfully implemented in Maryland.

para.heading: Membership.
para.text: The Working Group shall consist of no more than 15 members including:
The Secretary of the Environment, or the Secretary's designee;
The Secretary of Transportation, or the Secretary's designee;
The Chief Sustainability Officer;
One member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
One member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
One representative from OEMs, appointed by the Governor;
One representative from the Maryland Automobile Dealers Association, appointed by the Governor;
One representative from the Maryland Truck Association, appointed by the Governor;
Three representatives from Maryland environmental organizations, appointed by the Governor; and
Additional members appointed at the discretion of the Governor.

para.heading: Chair.
para.text: The Governor, or the Governor's designee, shall Chair the Working Group.
The Working Group shall meet as often as its duties require, but no less than monthly.
The Chair may convene meetings of the Working Group and shall preside over the meetings.
The Working Group may establish ad hoc committees that meet in between the Working Group's official monthly meetings.

para.heading: Reporting.
para.text: The Working Group shall submit a final report detailing its findings and recommendations to the Governor and General Assembly by December 31, 2025.
The Department of the Environment shall provide staff for the Working Group.

Members of the Working Group may not receive any compensation for their services, but may be reimbursed for their reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of duties in accordance with the State Standard Travel Regulations and as provided in the State budget.

para.heading: Implementation.
para.text: This Executive Order shall be implemented in a manner that is consistent with all applicable statutes and regulations. Nothing in this Executive Order shall operate to contravene any State or federal law or to affect the State's receipt of federal funding.

section.heading: Advancing In-Custody Restraint-Related Death Investigations in Maryland

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: The following words have the meanings indicated:
“Audit” means the independent audit of in-custody restraint-related death investigations that occurred between 2003-2019 at the OCME.

“Audit Report” means “An Independent Audit of Restraint-Related Death Investigations at Maryland’s Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) from 2003-2019,” published by the Office of the Attorney General’s Audit Design Team.

“In-Custody Restraint-Related Death” means sudden unexpected death during or shortly after physical restraint by law enforcement or other individuals including security guards, civilians, fire/EMS personnel, or corrections officers.

text.u: Authorizing the Attorney General to Re-Evaluate & Investigate OCME Audit Cases

para.text: In consultation with the appropriate local State’s Attorney’s Office, the Maryland Attorney General is directed to review each case included within the Audit to determine if the case should be reopened for investigation. On or before December 31st of each calendar year, the Attorney General shall prepare an annual report on the status of the review of Audit cases until each case has been reviewed.
Upon request, the Maryland State Police may assist the Attorney General in conducting any resulting investigations.
Nothing in this Executive Order shall be interpreted to preclude local State’s Attorneys’ Offices from reopening and initiating their own investigations into any case included within the Audit.

aftertext.u: Maryland Task Force on In-Custody Restraint-Related Death Investigations

para.heading: Establishment.
para.text: There is hereby established a Maryland Task Force on In-Custody Restraint-Related Death Investigations (“Task Force”).

para.heading: Membership.
para.text: The Task Force shall consist of the following members:
The Executive Director of the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, or the Executive Director’s designee, who shall serve as Chair;
Two (2) members appointed by the Attorney General;
One (1) member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
One (1) member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
The Public Defender, or the Public Defender’s designee;
The Secretary of Health, or the Secretary’s designee;
The Chief Medical Examiner, or the Chief’s designee;
The Superintendent of the State Police, or the Superintendent’s designee;
The Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, or the Secretary’s designee;
One (1) member of the Maryland Judiciary, appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Maryland; and
The following members appointed by the Governor:
Two (2) members from the Maryland State’s Attorneys’ Association;
One (1) member from the Maryland Chiefs of Police Association or Maryland Sheriffs’ Association;
One (1) member from a local law enforcement agency with expertise in policing standards, restraint, and use of force;
One (1) member with expertise in mental health and crisis intervention;
One (1) member from a community organization that works primarily to improve circumstances and outcomes for crime victims and families of decedents;
Two (2) members with expertise in forensic pathology and/or medicolegal death investigations, with at least one member having trained as a medical examiner; and
Two (2) members from the Governor’s Executive Office.

para.heading: Duties.
para.text: The Task Force, led by the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, shall:
Identify ways to improve in-custody restraint-related death investigations in the State;

Make recommendations on the establishment of a multidisciplinary statewide oversight committee to review future manner-of-death determinations for all in-custody restraint-related deaths within the State;
Based on the re-evaluation of each case included in the Audit, consider ways to reduce the risk of in-custody restraint-related deaths;

In consultation with the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission, evaluate the current standards for law enforcement agencies to document and investigate in-custody restraint-related deaths, and if necessary, make recommendations to improve Maryland’s training policies and ensure that they meet or exceed national standards;

Explore the intersection of police encounters, mental health and substance abuse, and in-custody restraint-related deaths and identify opportunities to promote greater collaboration between law enforcement and other agencies with specific expertise, such as mental health and substance abuse professionals; and
Evaluate the need and feasibility of conducting a subsequent audit and commencing such an audit, if necessary.
The Task Force shall be staffed by the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention and Policy.
Members appointed by the Governor shall serve at the pleasure of the Governor.

Members of the Task Force may not receive any compensation for their services, but may be reimbursed for their reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of duties in accordance with the State Standard Travel Regulations and as provided in the State budget.
The Chair shall:
Oversee and lead the work of the Task Force;
Determine the Task Force's agenda; and
Identify additional support as needed.
A majority of the members present shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business of the Task Force.
The Task Force shall meet as often as its duties require, but no less than quarterly.
The Chair may convene meetings of the Task Force and shall preside over the meetings.
The Task Force may establish ad hoc committees or working groups that meet in between the Task Force’s official quarterly meetings.

para.heading: Reporting.
para.text: The Task Force shall submit a report to the Governor on or before December 31, 2026.

para.heading: Duration.
para.text: The Task Force shall terminate on December 31, 2027, unless extended by the Governor.

aftertext.u: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner

para.text: The Maryland Department of Health (“Department”) shall review the OCME’s current policies and procedures for conducting in-custody restraint-related death investigations and clearly identify any changes that have taken place since 2019.
The Department shall review the practice and policy recommendations provided in the Audit Report and conduct a need-based analysis for implementing the recommendations related to the OCME.
The Department shall work with OCME to improve how in-custody restraint-related deaths are investigated including:
Facilitating additional training for medical examiners; and
Ensuring the Office implements and follows the National Association of Medical Examiner’s recommendations for in-custody restraint-related deaths.

The Department, in conjunction with OCME, shall submit a report to the Governor by December 31, 2026, detailing its progress in carrying out the duties outlined in Sections K through M of this Executive Order.

This Executive Order shall be implemented in a manner that is consistent with all applicable statutes and regulations. Nothing in this Executive Order shall operate to contravene any State or federal law or to affect the State's receipt of federal funding.

If any provision of this Executive Order or its application to any person, entity, or circumstance is held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions or applications of the Executive Order shall remain in effect to the extent possible without the invalid provision or application. To achieve this purpose, the provisions of this Executive Order are severable.

Except as provided in Paragraph J, this Executive Order applies to all employees in the Executive Branch of the State of Maryland, including employees of agencies with independent salary setting authority or independent personnel systems.

The Secretary of Budget and Management (Secretary) shall establish a Voluntary Separation Program (Program) that provides eligible State employees with a monetary payment of $20,000 plus $300 for each year of service as an incentive for employees to voluntarily separate from State service. The Program shall also include other severance benefits established by the Secretary including continuation, for those who are already enrolled, of State subsidized medical, prescription and dental benefits coverage, as well as life insurance coverage, for six months and payment for leave accrual in accordance with applicable law.

The Secretary shall establish criteria for employee participation in the Program and shall provide all eligible employees with sufficient information about the program to allow them to make fully informed decisions.
The Program shall be completely voluntary, and no employee shall be in any way compelled, coerced, or pressured, directly or indirectly, to participate.

Interested employees may apply to participate in the Program by filing an application with the Secretary. The agency employing an applicant shall advise the Secretary if the employee is in a position that should not be abolished. After the recommendations of employing agencies are considered, the applicants shall be notified if their application is approved or denied.
The filing of an application shall not create a right to participate in the Program. Only employees whose applications are approved by the Secretary shall be permitted to participate in the Program.

Employees accepted into the Program shall agree that they will not seek or accept employment or work in any capacity, including as an employee, contractor, or employee of a contractor, with any Executive Branch agency, public institution of higher education, or any other State agency or unit for a period of 18 months following their voluntary separation. An employee accepted into the Program who violates this reemployment prohibition shall be required to reimburse the State for the full amount of the severance payment and the cost of the subsidized health benefits.
The positions of all employees accepted into the Program shall be abolished.

The Secretary, the heads of every other personnel system, and the appointing authorities shall take all action as necessary or desirable to implement the Program. The Secretary, the heads of every other personnel system, and the appointing authorities shall implement the Program with the least possible disruption to the provision of State services.
This Executive Order does not apply to:
The Legislative Branch;
The Judicial Branch;
Persons holding any civil office of profit or trust under the Maryland Constitution;

Employees of the Attorney Grievance Commission, the Baltimore City Sheriffs Office, Canal Place Preservation and Development Authority, the Chesapeake Bay Commission, Historic St. Mary's City Commission, Maryland 529, all local health departments, the Injured Workers' Insurance Fund, the Maryland African American Museum Corporation, the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund, the Maryland Environmental Service, the Maryland Food Center Authority, the Maryland Stadium Authority, Maryland School for the Deaf, and the Registers of Wills;
Cabinet officials, agency heads, and members of any board or commission;

Positions, classifications, and agencies or parts of agencies designated as exempt from the Program by the Secretary, which generally, but not exclusively, include police officers, correctional officers, health care providers, emergency responders; and

Employees of the University System of Maryland, Baltimore City Community College, St. Mary's College of Maryland, and Morgan State University; however the University System of Maryland, Baltimore City Community College, St. Mary's College of Maryland, and Morgan State University may implement voluntary separation programs at each university in accordance with its rules and regulations and subject to the approval of its governing board.

section.heading: Valuing Opportunity, Inclusion, and Community Equity (VOICE)

para.text: “State Agency” means a department, agency, commission, board, council, or other body of State government subject to the direction and supervision of the Governor.
“Overburdened Community” has the meaning provided in §1-701(a)(7) of the Environment Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.

To ensure consistent, equitable, and fair distribution of State resources, all State Agencies that are Members of the Interagency Environmental Justice and Equity Advisory Council, established by Section C, below, shall use the Environmental Justice Mapping Tool, created by the Department of the Environment, to track and address disparities related to environmental hazards, exposures, risks, health outcomes, investments, and benefits.

State Agencies shall prioritize opportunities for meaningful engagement with impacted communities on policies and priorities related to Environmental Justice and that enable these communities to meaningfully inform State Agency decision-making.

State Agencies shall identify and implement mechanisms to increase resources and opportunities for historically underrepresented farmers, rural and urban, by reducing barriers for entry, such as land access, and financing.

para.heading: Interagency Environmental Justice and Equity Advisory Council (Council)
Establishment
para.text: There is hereby established the Interagency Environmental Justice and Equity Advisory Council (Council).

para.heading: Membership.
para.text: The members of the Council are appointed by the Governor, in collaboration with the Secretary of the Environment, and shall consist of the Chief Sustainability Officer and leader representatives from the following State agencies:
Department of Natural Resources;
Department of Transportation;
Maryland Port Authority;
Department of Agriculture;
Department of Housing and Community Development;
Department of Health;
Department of Planning;
Maryland Energy Administration;
Department of Commerce;
Department of Emergency Management;
Governor’s Office for Children;
Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
Department of Budget and Management; and
Other officials of State Agencies as the Governor or Secretary of the Environment may from time to time designate.

para.heading: Chair.
para.text: The Deputy Secretary of the Environment shall serve as Chair of the Council, and the Assistant Secretary of the Environment shall serve as Vice Chair of the Council:

para.heading: Duties.
para.text: The Council shall:

Support and facilitate interagency collaboration on programs and activities related to environmental justice, including the development of training plans to build the capacity and understanding of employees to advance environmental justice and to increase the meaningful participation of communities with environmental justice concerns;

Identify and leverage State and federal resources to develop and implement outreach adaptation and mitigation strategies that improve environmental health outcomes, particularly for overburdened coastal, rural, tribal and urban communities;

Develop strategies across State Agencies to stack federal grant opportunities, utilizing and leveraging multiple funding sources in parallel, to maximize investments and benefits for overburdened and rural communities;

Identify strategies to expedite and streamline the delivery of State and federal funding to overburdened and rural communities that lack existing resources to utilize a reimbursable grant funding framework and provide technical assistance;

Within each member agency of the Council, designate an Environmental Justice Officer responsible for leading agency planning and implementation of the agency’s Environmental Justice Strategic Plan, in a manner that seeks to reflect the rich diversity of Maryland;

Engage, collaborate, and consult with policy and community experts on Environmental Justice to conduct analyses and develop tools, including by building on and collaborating with existing bodies, as appropriate such as the Commission on Environmental Justice and Sustainable Communities (CEJSC), the Children's Environmental Health and Protection Advisory Council (CEHPAC), the Maryland Commission on Climate Change, the Governor’s Subcabinet on Climate, the Sustainable Growth Subcabinet and the Chesapeake Bay Cabinet;

Engage, collaborate, and consult with impacted communities on programs and activities related to environmental justice; including to receive their input on the development of the Environmental Justice Strategic Plans;
Track the overall spending of State and federal capital that has benefited overburdened and disadvantaged communities;

Assess the efficiency and accessibility of conservation programs and other resources for farmers and watermen in overburdened and underrepresented communities and develop strategies to address barriers;

Develop an enhanced public participation plan for communities with Environmental Justice concerns potentially affected by certain resource extraction, waste management, industrial and manufacturing processes and activities;
Assist local governments in ensuring that all residents, regardless of their background, have equitable access to a healthy environment by;

Upon request, providing technical assistance to local government entities, including incorporated and unincorporated municipalities, urban, suburban rural counties and coastal areas, which can include guidance on developing and implementing environmental justice programs, conducting impact assessments with an equity lens, identifying funding opportunities, and navigating complex regulatory frameworks; and

Encouraging and supporting the formation and implementation of local environmental justice initiatives by developing model plans and policies, hosting workshops and trainings, and facilitating partnerships between community based organizations and academic institutions;

Identify and make recommendations to the Governor to address potential disproportionate environmental and health impacts that State laws, regulations, policies, and activities may have on Maryland residents and ensure the benefits are shared equitably; and;
Make recommendations to the Governor to ensure consistency with federal Environmental Justice programs.
The Council shall meet at least quarterly.

In coordination with the Commission on Environmental Justice and Sustainable Communities (CEJSC), the Council shall hold at least two public meetings per year. Those public meetings shall include representatives from impacted communities.
The Council shall be staffed by the Department of the Environment.
Within 6 months of the date of this Order, the Chair shall issue guidance, in consultation with the CEJSC, to inform State Agencies of the implementation of this order.
The Chair may revise or issue additional guidance under this Order, as appropriate, and shall consider any additional recommendations made by the CEJSC in issuing or revising guidance

para.heading: Reporting.
para.text: The Council, led by the Department of the Environment, shall submit a report to the Governor’s Chief Sustainability Officer on or before December 1, 2025, and annually by December 1st each year thereafter, detailing the progress of implementing this Order. The Council’s annual reports shall be made available to the public.

para.heading: Environmental Justice Strategic Plans.
para.text: No later than 12 months after the date of this order and every 2 years thereafter, each agency member of the Council shall submit to the Chair and make available to the public, online, an Environmental Justice Strategic Plan with metrics to promote Environmental Justice in ways tailored to the specific agency and its authority, mission, and programs. Agencies must seek guidance from impacted stakeholders in the development of the metrics.

This Executive Order shall be implemented in a manner that is consistent with all applicable statutes and regulations. Nothing in this Executive Order shall operate to contravene any State or federal law or to affect the State’s receipt of federal funding.

If any provision of this Executive Order or its application to any person, entity, or circumstance is held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions or applications of the Executive Order shall remain in effect to the extent possible without the invalid provision or application. To achieve this purpose, the provisions of this Executive Order are severable.

para.heading: Establishment.
para.text: There is a Governor's Intergovernmental Commission for Agriculture (“Commission”).

para.heading: Voting Members.
para.text: The Commission shall consist of up to nineteen (19) voting members, including:
The Secretary of Agriculture or the Secretary’s designee, who shall serve as Chair;
A representative from each of the following organizations who shall be appointed by the Governor in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture:
The Maryland Agricultural Commission;
The Maryland Agricultural and Resource Based Industry Development Corporation;
The Maryland Association of Counties;
The Maryland Municipal League;
The Maryland Association of County Health Officers;
The Maryland Association of County Planning Officers;
The Maryland Farm Bureau; and
The Rural Maryland Council; and
Up to ten (10) members of the general public with interest or expertise in agriculture who shall be appointed by the Governor in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture.

para.heading: Non-Voting Members.
para.text: The Commission may also include the following members or their designee, who shall serve in an advisory non-voting capacity:
The Secretary of Planning;
The Secretary of Health;
The Secretary of Natural Resources;
The Secretary of the Environment;
The Secretary of Commerce;
The Secretary of Emergency Management;
The Secretary of Labor;
The Secretary of Human Services;
The Secretary of Aging;
The Secretary of Education;
The Director of the Maryland Energy Administration;
The Dean of the University of Maryland School of Agriculture and Natural Resources;
The Dean of the University of Maryland Eastern Shore School of Agricultural and Natural Sciences; and
The President of the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science.

para.heading: Duties and Responsibilities.
para.text: The Commission shall:

Work to increase the economic profitability of agriculture in the State by ensuring that all appropriate agencies work in a cooperative, coordinated manner with local government and industry groups to plan, implement, oversee and evaluate intergovernmental initiatives related to the agricultural affairs of the State;
Promote a clear and consistent “business-friendly” climate for agriculture in the State by serving as a liaison between the Governor and local governments and industry organizations;
Develop annual intergovernmental goals for services and functions dealing with the agricultural affairs of the State;
Develop and implement:
Procedures to identify and assess agricultural developments that could potentially impact the State and local governments;
A consistent, systematic method to coordinate the State’s agricultural economic development activities; and
Specific and measurable actions to improve the economic and regulatory climate for agriculture in the State;
Make recommendations for programs and policies to ensure that the needs and goals of the State’s agricultural strategy are met and accomplished; and
Perform other duties and responsibilities as assigned by the Governor.
The Commission shall be staffed by the Maryland Department of Agriculture. The State agencies represented on the Commission shall provide additional assistance as needed.
Members appointed by the Governor shall serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
Members representing an organization must maintain their specified organizational affiliation in order to maintain service on the Commission.

Members of the Commission may not receive any compensation for their services, but may be reimbursed for their reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of duties in accordance with the State Standard Travel Regulations and as provided in the State budget.
The Commission Chair shall:
Oversee and lead the implementation of this Executive Order and the work of the Commission;
Determine the Commission's agenda; and
Identify additional support as needed.
The Commission Chair may adopt bylaws, rules, and other procedures necessary to ensure the orderly transaction of business.
A majority of the voting members present shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business of the Commission.
The Commission shall meet as often as its duties require, but no less than twice annually.
The Chair may convene meetings of the Commission and shall preside over the meetings.
The Chair may establish subcommittees that meet in between the Commission’s official biannual meetings.

para.heading: Reporting.
para.text: The Commission shall submit an annual report to the Governor by October 1st each year, outlining its recommendations to support a coordinated agricultural strategy within the State.
